VEHICLE QUOTA SYSTEM
(Statement by the Minister for Communications and Information)


     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, on 26th February, 1990, I made a Ministerial Statement to Parliament where I announced the details of the vehicle quota system. I indicated then that after the quota system has been introduced, the tenders can be held monthly instead of quarterly to reduce fluctuations in tender premiums. I indicated also that with experience and feedback, we can make minor adjustments to improve the system.

    Sir, the first tender exercise was held in April 1990. The exercise went very smoothly. Since then, we have received much feedback from our members of the Government Parliamentary Committee on Communications and Information, Members of Parliament, the Feedback Unit and from the media. I want to thank all of them for their feedback which my Ministry has studied very carefully.

    Sir, today, I want to announce two minor adjustments to improve the quota system.

    Firstly, beginning July 1990, tenders will be held on a monthly instead of a quarterly basis. This will make it more convenient for prospective vehicle buyers. It will also minimise future fluctuations in premiums in between tenders. As a consequence of

Column: 172

this change, the maximum number of certificates of entitlement that will be available for each authorised motor distributor will be reduced from 100 to 30 for each tender.

    Secondly, the validity period of the temporary certificates of entitlement will be shortened from six months to three months. This reduction will apply to new certificates issued from the first monthly tender onwards.

    These changes will discourage speculation on the certificates.

    The first monthly tender will be held in July 1990. The tender will open from 9.00 am on Monday, 2nd July 1990 and will close at 4.00 pm on Wednesday, 11th July, 1990. As a consequential change, the number of vehicle entitlements available for tender would be one-third of that previously projected for the quarter August-October 1990. I have circulated a copy of the figures (Cols. 261 -262) for Members' information.

    The certificates issued from the tender in July will be valid from 1st August to 31st October 1990. This means that these certificates (those derived from the tender in July) will not enjoy the reduced ARF of 160% OMV because that will only be effective beginning 1st November, 1990.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Cheng San GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad to hear the Minister saying that the transferability period of the certificates will be reduced from six

Column: 173

months to three months. I am wondering why the Ministry, in spite of the feedback, is not prepared to consider dropping the idea of transferability completely.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, transferability plays a useful role in the allocation of the scarce resource, namely, the certificate of entitlement to buy a car. It enables this distribution to be made more effectively. Where you have a willing buyer and a willing seller, that is the best way for the free market to work. Hence, I would prefer that we keep transferability. What we have done is to discourage speculation which results when people think they can make large profits from transferability.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Third Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [11th June, 1990],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mr Lew Syn Pau].

    Question again proposed.
12.36 pm

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, on Monday, 11th June, 1990, the Straits Times carried a front page news headline on the kitchen that caved in at a flat in Bedok. I was saddened by the news because it is a fear that I had long ago and it came true. It was the pace in which we built flats and I was afraid of the lack of

Column: 174

supervision involved, and this actually happened.

    But what attracted my attention most, and I was very concerned, were the comments made by the HDB's Chief Executive officer, Mr Chuang Kwong Yong who said recently that:

    'Spalling concrete and other defects such as tiles popping up from floors were due to poor on-site supervision by the Board during the rush to build flats from 1980 to 1986.'

    The question in my mind is: how safe are the other flats built during the period 1980-86? Will cave-in likely to occur again? What assurances will the Board give to the owners of the flats built during that period? If poor supervision is the root cause, will HDB conduct a survey of all flats built during that period? With the Hotel New World still fresh in our memory, this fear is a very real one. I hope the HDB will advise on these matters to calm their fears.

    Reading the comments of the HDB's CEO, I cannot help thinking that his comments may be true in many other areas. Is it not true in years past that we were very concerned or sometimes very obsessed with numbers, quantities or achieving of goals in the shortest time possible? We are rightly proud that we build the greatest number of flats in record time. We are elated that our economic figures shot up in such a short period. We are very happy that so many foreign investments have been committed and, of course, not forgetting our MRT was completed in record time and ahead of schedule. And not forgetting that so many national events have been organised or will be held to celebrate the 25th anniversary. It is like going down the rapids where you have no time to stop to rest, to consolidate, and to review.

    But the biggest question I have is: granted that the form is impressive, what about the contents? We have been building flats for so many years, and did it not occur to our architects that our void decks are really void - void of activities, unfriendly and, in some blocks, very ghostly in the night? I was wondering to myself what is the purpose of void decks if they are not used daily by the residents.

Column: 175

Can we not design a more friendly void deck where residents can interact? Can we not cater for some snacks and refreshment stalls to brighten up the void decks? Yes, I think we have the greatest number of void decks in the world. But is it not better to have void decks which residents can find them useful?

    Our architects have been designing coffeeshops ever since HDB flats were built. Coffeeshop is our way of life. But I think we should take a look at our coffeeshop. The design of our coffeeshop is such that customers and patrons have got to compete with the heat coming out from the stalls. We all know that we like to sit in the open air to enjoy our food. Can we not design a better and more bearable coffeeshop which can then be our national identity? Just as in Europe, they have the sidewalk cafes as their identity there? I am sure if we stop, consolidate and review the designs, and not just be so caught up with numbers, I think we can come out with better designs.

    In the field of education, we have been very successful in producing students in great numbers with good results. One observation I have is that many of these students are poor in articulation and in application of their knowledge. Can this be because in our school system students have always been commanded to be quiet, speak only when spoken to, and if a child is outspoken he is labelled as talkative and sometimes penalised? Exposed and disciplined in such an environment for about 10 years in primary and secondary schools, it is possible that our students will graduate as we see them today. Yes, we produce many students, but what about their personal development?

    In business, we have always been very happy, and rightly so, to see so many big MNCs coming out with their foreign investments in Singapore. And also rightly so, our whole Government machinery is geared to promoting them and hoping that they would establish here to increase the economic pie that we have. But my concern is, in the midst of all this activity for attracting foreign businessmen to Singapore, the increase in foreign investments, what about the local businessmen? The local businessmen have always been

Column: 176

advised by Ministers and Government officials to automate and to go for overseas projects. Though the advices were well intended, the realities are that because we are clouded by the high investments of MNCs, we tend to pay relatively small attention to the local businessmen. I think that we should increase our focus to help the local businessmen so that they can be helped to go overseas.

    Recently, as you can see, there have been many Government-owned companies competing for the local business. These companies can do well because of many reasons. There are two main reasons. Many of these companies have no cash flow problems and their old boys' network is very large, especially among the Ministries. The achievements of these companies have blurred our vision of a possible disaster that can occur in the future. When these Government-owned companies grow in numbers and size, they will be very formidable. The biggest danger is when you have an inefficient government. Things can go very wrong. I have no doubt that this is unlikely for the next 15-20 years. But it will be prudent for us to anticipate such possibility.

    Touching on the quality of life in Singapore, our lifestyle is very much influenced by three factors, as I can see it, namely, the non-welfare state, productivity and meritocracy. The non-welfare state has unconsciously generated in us a sense of insecurity. We often hear people saying that they must save for rainy days. But there is a very thin line drawn between prudence and insecurity and, as such, it does not augur well for the psychology of our people.

    Next, productivity. In the area of productivity, usually the companies view it from their point of view. As such, productivity in Singapore has always been correlated very closely with long hours of work. The long hours that a person spends in work has resulted in very little time left for social interaction and recreation. This has created some problems.

    Finally, we have meritocracy. Although we must achieve excellence, meritocracy has an ugly side. Meritocracy has the

Column: 177

danger of producing a very selfish population, in that if one wants to excel, he or she would try to be the best and very often it means keeping information and not helping others. I admit that it is difficult to strike a balance between what we are doing and what I have said earlier. But I would like to suggest maybe one way to mitigate this situation is to create an environment in Singapore so that daily informal social interaction can take place instead of the organised events that we have in Singapore.

     Mr Davinder Singh (Toa Payoh GRC): Sir, I support the motion.

    The President has given us a general idea of how Singapore will be governed under the new leadership. Two features stand out in particular - consultative government and the Elected President. Whatever the merits of the Elected President, what impressed me were two vital ingredients which have been endorsed by the Government, ingredients which are vital to administration in any democracy. First, open government and, second, a system of checks and balances.

    Sir, a government which is detached, impervious and inscrutable can be effective but not indefinitely. It can only work where and for so long as you have people who due to their circumstances are preoccupied with other problems, for example, the need to survive. Our parents found themselves in that situation. They were out to sink roots in Singapore. Their primary concern was to earn a living and to do that, they needed a secure environment. They had come from places and backgrounds which had given them a real sense of insecurity and which encouraged them to play the game according to the rules, as it were. They were not likely to rock the boat or to allow anyone to do that if the result of that exercise were to increase the insecurity in Singapore. They had nothing to gain from challenging, questioning or taking issue with the manner in which government was run if that government was seen to be fair and honest. They had other problems on their mind.

Column: 178



    In that context, one can understand why in the 50s and the 60s it was not fashionable to demand for the rights which during that time had become cherished by the Americans - democratic ideals, in particular, the need for accountability. But we have come a long way. Due to education and information, we have been brought up to question, to assert our views, to demand respect and to take control of our own destinies. Gone are the days when Singaporeans would do what they are told to do because it is in the interest of themselves and in the interest of Singaporeans.

    Some of us see this as a degenerative trend which, if left unchecked, would result in a tearing of our social fabric. Measures have been put in place, for example, the reshaping of our educational policies and the encouragement of acquisition of cultural ballast. And in fact we have also been accused of over legislating. These measures have an effect but the effect will be limited. The process of westernisation is an inextricable one. There is no stopping people who have had the benefit of education and information from reaching out for western ideals, especially accountability. There is just too much information flowing into Singapore and the sources of such information will increase over time. Increasing numbers travel and they make up their own minds about the merits of one system over another. Satellite TV, as we all know, is at the doorstep and I personally cannot see how we can keep the door shut.

    Short of a calamity affecting the standing of the United States in the eyes of the world or affecting our livelihood, it is my view that this empathy for the need for accountability will strengthen with the passage of time. If the system is to survive, we must anticipate and accommodate these ideals of democracy. We must adapt our style and system of government so that we keep in tune with the mood, as it were. Participation in government is one such way and we have been doing that. I applaud that move. But we have to move further afield now.

    It is time that we changed the stony and sometimes disrespectful face of the public servant and made him accountable for his

Column: 179

decisions which affect the lives of the man-in-the-street. Accountability of the public service is, in my respectful view, the safest guarantee for the integrity and survival of the system. Hundreds of Singaporeans interact with public servants everyday and quite a few of them walk away extremely disgruntled for two reasons. One, the nature of the decision which is made in respect of their case and, two, the manner in which they are treated.

    As things stand today, public servants can make decisions without giving reasons for those decisions. And without reasons, how are we to know whether those decisions have been taken rationally, legally, in good faith and with full access to all relevant information?

    Most of us believe that the public service in Singapore is well oiled, fair, efficient. But there are many people who feel differently. These are the people who have had their applications rejected without reasons. These are people who have gone for assistance, for answers, to public servants but have been treated very badly, extremely shoddily. And their feelings for the Government must take a turn for the worse and with good reason. This is all very counter productive because, as we know, our Ministers spend a lot of time listening to members of the public, accommodating their views. They do their best to give members of the public as much access to them as is possible. What good is all of this going to do if the representative of the Government, which the man-in-the-street encounters everyday, is rude and is disrespectful?

    Sir, all of us are accountable. MPs are accountable to constituents. Judges are accountable to Appellate Judges. Ministers are accountable in a way. Public servants may well take the position that they are accountable to their respective Ministers in Parliament. But there is this theory of accountability of Ministers in Parliament which in practical terms works in a very limited way. We all know that in Parliament we debate legislation and we discuss policy matters through the legislative process. It is a very rare occasion when we get down into the nitty-gritty of individual complaints, ie, complaints of constituents

Column: 180

in relation to their livelihood. We do not discuss these things in Parliament.

    It is in our interest, I suggest, that we develop a system of accountability, a system which will assure the man-in-the-street that if he has a grievance, he can take it to a person or a body who has a right or has power to look into it, look into the files of the Ministry, if necessary, or bring a complaint of shoddy treatment up to the superiors. This can be done by appointing a commissioner, or what in other jurisdictions is called an Ombudsman, with powers to look into complaints, with powers to redress grievances about treatment.

    Alternatively, the terms of reference of the Feedback Unit could be widened. So people with legitimate grievances can come forward and feel and believe that there is someone willing to listen to them and someone willing to take something up. At the same time, I would ask Government to consider changing the entire system about not giving reasons when decisions are made rejecting applications. Reasons should be given as far as possible. If reasons are given, constituents or MPs, on constituents' behalf, can know the reasons why an application is unsuccessful and take steps to address that problem. If more information is required, obtain that information. If guidelines have not been complied with, then the man-in-the-street will know what he has to do to comply with the relevant guidelines. If these steps are put in place, Sir, people will believe that they are being given fair treatment. If that is the case, Sir, there will be very little reason, or at least less reason, for them to be upset with the system. Our system cannot be hurt if we experiment with an exercise to ensure fair play.

     Mr Lim Boon Heng (Kebun Baru): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I touch on the subject which I intended to speak on, I must say a few words about what the Member for Paya Lebar has said concerning the HDB. Let me declare my interest. I am a member of the Board of Directors of HDB. I think that the CEO of HDB was being frank when he said that during the rush to build so many flats the on-site supervision by the Board was poor and that HDB now has a programme to correct all these defects. An

Column: 181

unfortunate event happened in Bedok where in the repair of spalling concrete, the floor caved in. A statement has been made by the HDB on this. We still do not know completely what happened because there are a number of things which could have given cause to this unfortunate accident. The Member for Bedok GRC, Dr Hong Hai, has asked for a full explanation and I think we should await for a full explanation of this incident before we jump to the conclusion that the buildings are unsafe for habitation. I think the last thing that we should do, as responsible Members of Parliament, is to cause panic. We should not cause panic among the people.

    Members will also recall in the statement of the HDB that with respect to the particular case in the block concerned, HDB has given an assurance that the building is safe and that the fault has not affected the structural integrity of that particular building. So I think we should all sit back and wait for the HDB's full explanation in response to the Member for Bedok GRC before we make any further statements on this.

    Sir, let me now turn to the subject that I wish to speak on. Here I must first express my support for the motion standing in the name of the Member for Tanglin.

    The most significant event of this session of Parliament is the impending leadership transition. The preparation has been thorough and we will see a smooth transition. But yet every change must bring with it a different environment and possibly unexpected results. It is said that the style of Government will change to reflect the character and thinking of the new man at the helm. But styles may change to fit the needs of the times. We cannot preclude that there will be no other developments, planned or unplanned, that may be in store as a result of change. The forces of history are not under the control of any one man. A strong personality can influence the cause of history but cannot control totally the course of history. As such, we must be prepared for change, and whatever that may come our way. To

Column: 182

cope with change, we must be guided by certain constants. What are these constants? These are fundamental values on which our society is founded. On these values, policies are shaped. These core values are those we share in common. These are values which our multi-racial, multi-religious society hold as fundamental for the maintenance of peace and harmony without which progress and prosperity cannot be achieved.

    First and foremost, is the principle that every citizen of Singapore has an equal and rightful place, irrespective of race, language or religion.

    Before 1959, I was in primary school. At that time I could not fully understand what was going on in our island except that the British were the masters and we were not of the same status as them. Singaporeans were not happy over this state of affairs, and demanded the right to manage our own destiny.

    In 1959, we made the first step to independence, with internal self-government. It was an event of great rejoicing, when all Singaporeans felt that at last we had made one significant step upwards - from being a subject people, towards full nationhood.

    What followed was merger with Malaysia. It was welcome. At last we attained full independence. The Federation held out great promise. The future was ours to shape.

    By then, I was in secondary school. It seemed to me then, that the path to the promised land was, to put it mildly, rocky. We were all Malaysian citizens, but why were there differences between bumiputras and non-bumiputras? As a non-bumiputra, I felt a sense of gross injustice that I was less than equal to others as a citizen.

    A few years later, during my undergraduate days in the United Kingdom, I was to meet Malaysians, mostly Chinese. They felt strongly the sense of injustice that there were no equal opportunities for everyone, that race was first and foremost in most things. I could well understand why some of them even talked of joining Chin Peng in the jungles.

Column: 183



    For us in Singapore, our union with Malaysia was to be shortlived. We were on our own in August 1965. When our Prime Minister said soon after separation, and I quote:

    'We are going to have a multi-racial nation in Singapore. This is not a Malay nation, not a Chinese nation, not an Indian nation.'

I could fully share this value. I could fully identify myself with this principle.

    Having been a minority, I was fully prepared to extend to the minorities in our small country an equal place in our nation as his basic right. This was a principle that the vast majority of Singaporeans could agree upon. Singapore cannot be founded on the superiority of any one race. The only basis is that of equality of all races, with the right to use his own language, and to practise his own faith. The PAP included this as one of its fundamental planks - this has been repeated in its manifestos, and enshrined in its constitution. Today, one of its objectives in its constitution reads as follows, and I quote:

    'To forge a nation of Singaporeans; to build a multi-racial society, fair, just and tolerant to all, whatever their race, language and religion; to infuse into Singaporeans a sense of national identity and to bind them together by patriotism and commitment to Singapore.'

    Because the PAP held this out as a fundamental principle to all, Singaporeans identified with the PAP, and the PAP won the support of the people.

    It has been because of this fundamental principle that we have enjoyed peace and harmony, in spite of our multi-racial and multi-religious character. Not all multi-racial and multi-religious countries have been so similarly fortunate.

    This is a fundamental principle on which our nation is based. It must remain so, if we are to continue to enjoy peace and harmony. Therefore, the Government, under a new leader, must continue to abide by this principle. We should take care, when new policies are formulated, that we do not breach this basic principle. I know that equality has been the cornerstone of all Government policies. In the implementation of policies, however, fair play and justice may not be seen to be upheld by our minority races. If this is so,

Column: 184

and where this is so, we should correct them.

    Equality extends not only to consideration of race, language or religion. Each citizen must have equal opportunity in all things, whatever his station in life. This has been also one of the fundamental principles upheld by the PAP.

    For example, education has been open to all. It has been the policy of the PAP that every child shall have a place in school. He should be given whatever help necessary to achieve the highest level of education that he is capable of. Because of this, whether from rich or poor, a child can rise up in society. For the poor, this is especially important, as it holds up the hope that if they themselves are not able to enjoy the good life, then at least their children can aspire to that. This again is fundamental to peace and harmony in our society. In fact, so important is this principle that it has also been enshrined in the current PAP constitution, and I quote:

    'Within the overriding interest of the good of society, to provide equal opportunities for all Singaporeans to strive to fulfil themselves and to achieve their maximum potential through education and training so that there will be a place and a role for every Singaporean, whatever his contribution.'

    Today, we may take these two fundamental principles for granted. But it bears restating these fundamentals on which the policies of the new administration will be based. Today, we are searching for shared values, to enshrine them as the basis of our nationhood. We must ensure that every citizen shall have an equal and rightful place in our society. Beyond this, we must find values we share in common, values that bind us together.

    The search, in fact, was commenced much earlier than the past couple of years. It started even just after we attained independence on our own. For example, Mr Lim Kim San said in the 60s that Singapore's most urgent task was to find a common national framework for people of different races, languages, religions and cultures. From what I know, we have right now the World Conference of Girl Guides in Singapore. The organisers make sure that students from various schools and of various races work together. I know this because my child is studying in one of the SAP schools. Her partner is a Malay student. They have been working happily together.

Column: 238

listened to Dr Lau Teik Soon just now and I have also read Dr Tay Eng Soon's suggestion that we should have a Singapore Cultural Month among the ethnic groups. Firstly, we must understand one thing: if we do not have a Singapore culture, how are we going to hold a Singapore culture month? How could we have a drama performance if we have not written the scripts? If we merely put the art performances, handicraft, and food stalls of Chinese, Malay, and Indian, can we call this a Singapore culture? I remember I read an article in a book called "Management of Success". There is a formula: S = C + M + I + O. S represents Singapore, C for Chinese, M for Malay, I for Indians and O for others. After 25 years, we have developed a strong sense of national consciousness. We are proud of the success of Singapore, we are proud of not only the SIA, Changi Airport, and our Prime Minister, but also many of our achievements, but this does not mean that we already have our Singapore culture. Let me give an example: Members of Parliament often go in groups to other countries to represent Singapore. The delegation may comprise MPs from various ethnic groups, and the MPs may deliver speeches to defend the interest of Singapore. We behave like Singaporeans. But when we are having our meals, we have to be conscious of the differences of our religions and the customs of different ethnic groups.

Column: 239

pressure cooked. Some observed that the Americans established their own literature only after Mark Twain published his work. So, we should not be too hasty in the development process towards a Singapore culture. Of course, we have the Singapore dress and things which are Singaporean, for example, hawker food, but this does not necessarily represent the Singapore culture.

    Given the thinking of some of our highly educated Singaporeans and the inherent problems of our pluralistic society, the Maintenance of Religious Harmony Bill and the White Paper on Shared Values are of great significance. This is a clear example of our far-sighted political leaders who are leaving no stones unturned to make sure that there is peace and harmony among our races and religions. The Maintenance of Religious Harmony Bill is a preparation for the rainy days in anticipation of any possible mishap and to reduce any inter-religious friction and to prevent people from making use of religion to attain political objectives. The White Paper on Shared Values is an attempt to seek common ground in diversity. It is to list out the values shared by our people from the various ethnic groups so that the cohesiveness of society can be strengthened and that we could develop our own characteristics. The shared values are not merely a formal statement. They serve as a guidance and code of conduct for Singaporeans and for future generations. If we can always put national interest and collective interest before our own individual interest, then it will help our people to reduce their self-contrednes and individualism, or even to reduce the desire to emigrate. If we place great importance on 'family' then we would not have, as what Mr Eugene Yap has described, people who are unfilial to their parents or couples who are hostile to each other. If we can inculcate mutual tolerance and mutual respect, then we should be able to avoid conflicts between races or religions. If we try to deal with problems in a consultative, and not confrontational manner, then we would be able to build consensus and solve many problems in a harmonious way.

    When we enter the new phase, we shall face many new problems which are intan-

Column: 240

gible and related to emotions and inner thought. For example, how to build up a cohesive society? How to strengthen the sense of identity with our nation? How to encourage people to participate in decision-making? How to strengthen the ties between the people and the leaders? These are new challenges that we have to take. We cannot have something like a cultural revolution to purify the thoughts of our people. We must also not depend on satay or char kway teow or soup kambing to group our people together. We must be frank and sincere and solve our problems together in a consultative manner. We must share with our people our aspirations and concerns. We must accommodate those who oppose us and instil more confidence in our people in the second generation leaders. We must build up new bridges or new channels between the people and the Government so that we can work together for a better future.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tiong Bahru GRC): Sir, over the last few days of debate, we have heard many fellow Members talk at length about our new style of participatory government - ruling by consensus - and caring for the lower income group, and many other issues, although they are not burning ones.

Sir, I have in mind three areas - leadership and consensus, market economy and the lower income group, and work ethics and social refinements.

    First on consensus building and leadership. By and large, the changing style of government and governing by consensus is welcomed by a new generation of better educated Singaporeans. It is agreed that there should also be more participation from the people, but it should not be from a select group but a wider one. Consultation with people should not be seen as mere lip service but be genuine, lest the people think that irrespective of their views, the Government will push through

Column: 241

its proposed legislation, whatever is said. However, I would like to add a word of caution in case we get carried away and forget that ultimately the Government must govern, dissenting views notwithstanding.

    We have to guard against carrying the question of consultation to an extreme. As in the past of hard-headed leadership, if a bitter pill must be swallowed for the good of the country and strong measures implemented despite popular resistance, the Government should not flinch, but should proceed even if consultation with the people shows its unpopularity. In this I applaud our First Deputy Prime Minister when he was quoted as saying that he is not going to count hands in the Cabinet. I am also glad to hear from him just a moment ago that he will not govern by the opinion polls. There is no contradiction in his style of building consensus and putting his foot down. The art of government is indeed the ability to seek a balance between seeking views and opinions and selling a hard decision. It is not to go to the people on each and every single issue. I believe the right mix and balance will come when our next Prime Minister establishes that level of rapport and trust with the people which is enjoyed by the Prime Minister. Many Singaporeans will agree with me that when I say we want participation, we also need strong leadership.

    On the lower income group and the market economy, Sir, I have spoken out for the lower income group on several occasions in this House. A number of my honourable colleagues have also covered this subject with much passion in the last two days. Despite the burgeoning middle class, the plight of the lower income group is a matter close to the hearts of hon. Members. We can identify with them because most of us come from that very same background. We see in them shades of ourselves and our family.

    However, at the same time, as rational and thinking people, we also realise, as do many East European populations, that a market economy is the only workable system which will bring the desired

Column: 242

benefits to the people. A market economy is efficient, effective and allocates resources with the least wastage. This being so, it seems to be a ruthless weapon and strikes fear in those not accustomed to this effectiveness. This very fear is one which East Germans now face in the union with West Germany -the fear that a market economy tends to penalise those who are less able and privileged.

    Hence, the question for the Government to address is not whether we should or should not privatise this or that service. The question to ask is how do we do so without pushing our less privileged into an even more disadvantaged position. In this, I am certain the views expressed by my colleagues, Dr Vasoo and Dr Koh Lam Son, are worthy of consideration. Dr Vasoo's call for graded services is in fact the opposite side of the same coin of our progressive tax structure, and that is, the more able should shoulder more without letting this becoming a disincentive.

    We have always urged our people to be more compassionate and show more concern for the less fortunate in our society. Besides the 25th Anniversary Charity Fund, our people have responded positively in many other ways. As for the Government, this question of the poor has been continually highlighted in each President's Address since I became a Member of this House. It is time therefore that the Government set the example and put into concrete form by adopting some of the suggestions brought up by my colleagues. This will not only send a positive signal to our people, but will go down well with the people.

    I welcome the First Deputy Prime Minister's undertaking just a moment ago that more practical measures will be put into place in the next few months. Here, indeed it is the real challenge to the Government - of how to balance efficiency of privatisation and, at the same time, easing the burden of those who are most adversely affected.

    Sir, the last area I want to highlight is social refinements and work ethics. I wish to pose this question to the House and to all Singaporeans. We have reached a high level of economic development which few

Column: 243

can deny, but have we arrived? Have we as a nation, and a people, attained that level of maturity and graciousness that marks the great civilisations of the world? We have acquired the trappings of comfortable living, but have we imbibed the nectar of life?

    My humble submission is that we have yet to acquire the social refinements that mark a long established and mature society. We are more like the nouveau riche. We have the money but we still lack the social graces that mark a great nation. How else do you explain the phenomenon of Singaporeans piling up on their buffet plates with more than they can possibly consume just because the price tag covers all they can eat? I believe, Sir, that we need time to grow, and to arrive in the real sense of the word. What we are is to some extent no fault of our people's. It is just that - like good wine - we also need time to mature.

    I would, therefore, urge our new leaders to set as our next national goals, superseding even that of economic development, the nurturing of social refinements and our people as a great people. Like the man who strives to get out of his fishing village by succeeding in the big and rough city, and then working day and night so as to have the luxury of going fishing, let us not lose sight of the philosophical and social side of economic development.

    At the same time, as we go for the softer aspects of life, social refinement, culture, music and the arts, we should not lose sight of what brought us here - our survival instincts and our relentless pursuit of economic growth. Are these two objectives contradictory? Must we lose one to gain the other?

    My view, Sir, is that we can have both. First, by continuing to emphasise and not lose sight of meritocracy as an important foundation or pillar of our system; and secondly, by working smart. Computers, office automation and the new technologies will give us the additional edge we will need to improve ourselves economically and still have the time for more leisure activities and a more refined life-style. We need not equate a more relaxed life-style as a dent in our work ethics so

Column: 244

long as we are better equipped with the new tools and technologies.

    The real challenge is how to instill in our people the survival instincts of our forefathers and the older generation and, at the same time, pursue the trappings and refinements of a developed society. This, I believe, is a balance which will be struck over time.

    Sir, the marathon goes on. Some may say the next leaders' task is fine-tuning what has been achieved and passed on to them. I submit that our task is more than this. There are greater heights to scale and we have completed but one leg of our marathon and the end is not in sight.

    While we identify the goals for the new milieu, I submit we should strive not for the good years - as historically we have not yet had that many - but for better years. Our future development should not be one based preponderantly on economic yardsticks. Instead, it should now be based on social ones as well.

    To be judged to be successful, the Government has to meet the contradictions I have highlighted. Of even more importance is the ability of the new leadership to establish the kind of rapport and understanding with our people - the understanding that when we reach out to the young, we are not alienating the elderly; that when we cater to the middle class, we have not forgotten the less fortunate; and that when we search for life's refinements, we are not seen to de-emphasise hard work.

    Sir, I support the motion standing in the name of the Member for Tanglin.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua)( In Mandarin): Sir, actually many important points have already been brought up in Parliament by my colleagues and the First Deputy Prime Minister. But I still wish to make use of this opportunity to raise some of my own personal views.

Column: 247

Prime Minister as the Father of Singapore, nothing can be more appropriate than that.

To me, put simply, all these have to do with what our future leaders, our parents, corporate bodies, our social and cultural activities. More importantly, it has to do with our education system and its implementation in deciding what sort of a society Singapore will become.

    When I studied the information I received from the Ministry of Education, what moved me was that fact that we have set aside $2 billion in our budget for education. This is more than in New Zealand. Australia has a population seven times our population, but what they spend on is only four times of what we are spending. So we are indeed putting a lot of emphasis on education. What I am talking about is not education in its narrow sense. This not only includes formal education. I will first talk about formal education and then general education. In order to provide parents with more choices and in an effort to raise the general standard of education , what we have done in increasing our universities and higher tertiary institutions

Column: 248

is credible. But I feel in order to cultivate a creative society perhaps the Government needs to consider allocating more funds on research. And as for primary and secondary schools, I am happy to see in the Addendum on the Ministry of Education plans are underway to convert secondary and primary schools into full-day schools. And I think this should not be delayed any more. But before we launch the full-day system, during this transitional period, what we should do is to help some schools which have shown a willingness in providing before and after school care. I think the Government should give them the necessary financial and personnel support.

    Another point that I am happy to see is that the Ministry of Education has also aimed at raising the quality of staff in primary school. But I have on several occasions raised in the House that 90% of our pre-school children attend day care and kindergarten before they enter primary school. So I hope the Ministry of Education, besides putting efforts at improving the quality of primary school staff, they should also help to train pre-school and kindergarten staff as well. As our Prime Minister said in 1974 in the World Teachers' Seminar, no matter how advanced and good the facilities are more important is the relationship between the teachers and the students, as a positive relationship, can help motivate the child to reach his potential in learning. Such relationship also serves to help children in their formative years form a positive attitude towards life. Therefore, in the process of formulating a syllabus for our national values, I think the most important factor is teachers' qualification because they serve as models for our next generation. So I think while improving our teaching aids, we must also work on this teacher/pupil relation and their moral education. This is what I call formal education.

    The next point which is more important is adult education. The fact that our parents often put pressure on their children is because under the present system formal education is the only way to success and it is only through university education that their children can become a lawyer, engineer, doctor, etc. But we know

Column: 249

that in may advanced countries they put a lot of emphasis on adult education, especially in terms of technical training. So a child does not necessarily have to attend university to become a professional engineer. This is especially true in Germany where their vocational training in line with the work a person does. Through opportunities in night school, and open-university and Television school they can become engineers. If we can strengthen this type of remedial education in the adult education project, I can be certain that parents and the society will change their attitude towards education, that is to say, every person in every stage of his life can continue to learn. Therefore, I call on the Ministry of Education that although expenses in this area can be high and cost of per capita investment is high, they should consider it so that those who do not make it in the formal education system may be able to work towards a professional certificate. At the moment, most people's attitude towards VITB is biased and I think this is wrong. They see VITB students as naughty kids.

    But lately from what the VITB has done in raising charity fund. I can see they are concerned members of the society. They have raised $400,000. For these children, our objective should be how to tailor courses for these students to suit their work, so they can continue to attend night class and eventually get that professional qualification. Only this way will parents change their attitude towards VITB. Perhaps this has to do with the negative attitude our society has towards those who work with their hands.

    What Germany and Japan have achieve today, I believe, stem from the importance and respect they place on technical personnel. Although I believe a name may not be that important, psychologically, many may still be bogged by the negative image on VITB. Therefore, I suggest changing VITB's image into a vocational training board may be more appropriate, thus changing parents' concept towards VITB.

Column: 250

from many factors. I trust the minister knows more than I do. When we visited the various factories in various countries, training for workers in Japan is continuous and it is not based on individual stages of production but according to the 5-year or 10-year plan of the company.     What I have touched on has to do with a certain aspect of human quality and it involves the way they earn a living and their training. The other aspects are the moral attitudes and spiritual development and what we were debating about - a national identity. This needs more time. Personally, what I feel is the most important factor or an indirect means is not through talk or through celebrations. More important, every one should serve as an example. What we believe and what we do will effect our next generation. Our political leaders are chosen by us and we choose them because we have our aspirations and expectations on them. But we cannot say that they must comply with the wishes of the people in every way. Let us say, everyone may aspire for a car. Sometimes an individual's aspirations may come into conflict with our national interest, then there must be control. Take our second language requirement, for example, if parents were given a choice, although they can appreciate the advan-

Column: 251

tage of learning the mother tongue, for obvious benefits and to lighten their children's load, they would drop it. Given a choice, children may not even want to study it at all. So I am happy to hear the First Prime Minister say that he will not rule by the count of hands and that he will not mislead the people to win popular votes. I am happy to see that our successors have this firm stand and we fully support them in continuing to bring Singaporeans a better life.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Encik Yatiman Yusof)( In Malay): Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to support the motion moved by the Member for Tanglin to express our thanks to the President for his Address at the opening of the Second Session of the Seventh Parliament on 7th June.

    Sir, the President's brief Address is Singapore's response to the challenges of the future. It reflects our aspirations and desires for the future, to create a Singapore of excellence and distinction, developed, mature, existing in an atmosphere of stability and peace. It is not a statement of unfulfilled desires, as claimed by the Member for Potong Pasir, but is in continuation and an enhancement of the real and concrete efforts we have taken so far.

    The President's Address was delivered at a very significant moment for Singapore. It was delivered while we are celebrating the 25th Anniversary of Singapore's independence. We are now at the threshold between two different generations, moving from a generation meeting the demands of independence to a generation evolving a society of excellence, from a generation seeking to fulfil basic needs, ie, food, clothing, housing, jobs, education and health, to a generation living comfortably, cultured, artistic and strong in human compassion, from a generation sufficient in physical requirements to one that has its inner and spiritual needs satisfied. We are now in the phase of a society approaching maturity.

    In this sense, we are entering a more difficult and complicated arena, one that will challenge our capability. We are moving from the state in which every step,

Column: 252

every action taken, every programme, are readily measured and gauged, into a state in which a common yardstick can no longer apply. This is because we are no longer faced with the responsibility of meeting just the needs of the masses, but also of satisfying the diverse and often arbitrary desires of the individual. In the past, we could come up with statistics to show what percentage of the population owned flats, how much they earned a month, what their qualifications were. Today, flat ownership is no longer the consideration. The question now is how meaningful it is and how satisfied one is with one's flat. The same applies to monthly income. It is no longer a question of just how much one earns, but what one can do with it. It is no longer a question of what one's educational qualifications are but what discipline is preferred, what purpose will the qualification serve and what satisfaction can one gain from it, having achieved it through such stiff competition in school. Sir, we are moving from tangible considerations to abstract considerations, from the objective to the subjective world.

    Another point I would like to make is that as a society achieves maturity, social stratification will appear, with all its attendant features and effects. Social stratification manifests itself not only in terms of income, social status and education, but also in terms of lifestyles and perception of life and a slower social mobility. As long as there are ample opportunities to climb the social ladder and social mobility is fast, we have little problems. But when we are faced with the situation now prevalent in the United States and Europe, where social mobility is so slow, we will have to do something before society falls apart.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, the higher our economic advancement and the more complex our infrastructure, the more specialisation would be required. This will mean more diverse tasks and roles for our citizens, leading in turn to differences in social perception. If these different perceptions are not homogenised through a set of shared values, we will encounter fresh problems.

    Signs in this direction began to surface some time ago in the commonly-held

Column: 253

ideas, particularly among parents, of the difference between white collar and blue collar jobs. As a result of public prejudice, parents became reluctant to send their children who are not performing well academically to vocational institutes.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, I cite the example of VITB trainees and graduates just to emphasise the importance of adopting and maintaining a positive attitude and social perception in our society. It is because of the need to evolve and uphold a set of shared values that the President dealt with the National Ideology in his Address. The thrust of his message is that we need to reach a consensus in our social attitudes towards and perceptions of each other regardless of race, religion, profession or income. Everyone of us has a role to play and a contribution to make and these form an inseparable part and, indeed, a guarantee, of our existence and well-being.

    Sir, we are now in the process of leadership transition. This is not a transition in the usual sense, but a transition in continuity. The Hon. Prime Minister will be

Column: 254

relinquishing his post by the end of the year. To the people of Singapore, he is the man who built, developed and moulded the independent Singapore that exists today.
